Don't Try To Be A
"Big Man"

A FRESH TALE
And have you heard about the
freshman here who Is in the chemistry
class which had to buy two books—
a text book and a lab manual. Anyhow, a reading assignment was made
In class, causing the poor first-year
student to grumble, "Gee whiz, they
never tell you anything in this school;
which book am I supposed to read?"

Congratulations to Hersh Cross on
his recent appontment as coach of
the Jay eleven and to Gardner Mallonee on his reelection as president
of 0. D. K.
Remember, we'd like to have other
dirt beside what is rapidly accumulating in P.O. Box 313.

their sage experience usually express
their advice through the medium of
the most sordid but useful word don't.
We have little advice to offer. We
have so little, in fact, that we nearly
waived our traditional advice-giving
privilege, hoping that their tumbles
into the great pitfalls of college life
would act as a better conditioner to
the frosh than the crash of weighty
words of wisdom upon their ears.
We are weak, though. We shall advise --once. And, what is worse, our
admonition is a don't. It is: "Don't
try to be a 'big man' on the campus.
Activities, most of the saner observers
of undergraduate life will aver, are
a salutary force in the life of the undengrad, but there is no more real
waste of the opportunity that college
offers than to tackle more activities
than you can handle. For all, except
potential Thomas A. Edisoru3, two activities should be a man's limit. If you
attempt more, the chance are about
five to one that you will either fail
to get the most out of your studies
or that you will bungle the activities.
You will probably do both."
Here our advice stops. Take it or
leave it. Go out for one or two activou will really enjoy the expe't keep your eyes the same

the central charm of the book lies in
the author's personality which shines

a group matter; of people working together to create the play as the playwrite conceived it. His greatest joy
is when some awkward youngster succeeds in feeling the part through his
whole body, and at last really belongs
to it. And then to see the effect of that
on the whole troupe.
So they come. Every year applications of hopefuls pour in. Only a few
can be accomodated. Some come, grow
discouraged, and leave. Others find
Openings in New York, Hollywood, or
some other Little Theatre group. A
few are successful as a result. Many
fit into parts in stock companies. And
then, of course, there are those who
stick. Stick because this gives them a
manner of living, a reason for living. To work and be always working,
to find something to be done everyminute. Satisfied with the theatre
they have got, glad to produce the
great plays of masters, and equally
happy to try some one of the many
manuscripts which pour into the mail
boxes, they try plays of seasons ago,
or of seasons to come. They welcome
any audiences, by not caring for the
audiences.
This troupe will be seen here in
Baltimore at the Auditorium, for
two performances on November 18. In
the afternoon, the play will be "The
Emperor's New Clothes." In the evening, Bernard Shaw's biting satire,
"Getting Married," will be shown. This
is the opening bill of the Hopkins
Playhouse, under the direction of Dr.
N. B. Fagin.

Dr. McClure Speaks
On International Pacts
Dr. Wallace McClure, of the Departtrient of State in Washington, yesterday delivered the first of a series
of lectures on "Problems Concerning
International Agreement Under the
American Form of Government. Every
Thursday hereafter at 11.30 he will
continue his series in Gilman Hall.
During the second semester he will
devote his time to the "Intimations
Of World Government." This topic will
be a sequel to the first and clarify
lasues stirred up by it.
This series was made possible by
Theodore Marburg, a trustee of the
University and a former United States
arnba.ssador to Belgium.

Dr. William 0. Weyforth, secretary
of the evening courses in business economics at the Johns Hopkins University, addressed members of the Delta
Sigma Pi honorary fraternity last
night in Levering Hall on trends in
economics. Arthur Bliss, president of
the group, introduced Dr. Weyforth.

Home Appearance
Gardner Mallonee's gridiron valiants stage their first home performance of the current season tonight
when they confront the Washington
College aggregation at the Homewood
Field.
The Jays will be seeking their first
victory over the Chestertown lads in
three years. Time there was when
the Washington tussle was merely
a warm-up drill for the Blue Jays
who concentrated upon other, more
potential, opponents. But tonight the
Hopkins team will be fighting madly
to humble an opponent which has
assumed a significant position on the
grid card.
Two years ago, a highly confident
Jay squad was upset by a welltrained, aggresive, and determined
Maroon eleven. To add to the humiliation of the defeat, Gibby Young,
elusive diminuitive quarterback, intercepted a pass behind Ns own goal
line, and twisting and dodging, reeled
off a 103 yard run to score a brilliant
touchdown last season.
A definitely superior Washington
squad downed a scrappy Hopkins
team by a narrow margin.
Thus the gridmen are intent upon
stemming the maroon and black tide
and enjoying a victory of vengeance.
The outcome of this evenings contest is significant in view of another
consideration. A Hopkins eleven has
failed to break into the win column
since 1934.

Still hungry for their firSt victory
of the season. the Blue Jay Booters
meet Salisbury State Teachers College tomorrow at Homewood. Smaring under last week's defeat at the
hands of Gettysburg, the team seeks
vengeance on its new opposition.
The Booters, already acknowledged
powerful defense is further strengthened by the return of Hartman after
an absence. At his old goalie post,
Hartman is playing the best soccer
of his career. From soccer-conscious
Greensboro High comes a new acquisition, Briggs, center forward, who,
together with Phillips, Hartke, and
Clisham, gives promise of building
up a Hopkins offensive to rival its

tine defense. And coupled with this
is Coach Frank Dotterweich's assurance that the Hopkins' team is now
supplied with the necessary stamina
to show the shoremen plenty of speed
on attack and defense. His conviction
is borne out by the fine exhibition of
offensive play at last Saturday's Gettysburg game, and the usual excellent defense, in spite of the fact that
the Jays went down in defeat in extra
periods.

The interfraternity touch football
league got off to its scheduled start
on Tuesday with the Sigma Phi Epsilon team registering a 24 to 6 victory over the Alpha Epsilon Pi representatives. At no time were the winners hard pressed and they contented
themselves with trying out their plays
rather than attempting to pile up a
huge score. Those scoring touchdowns
for the victors were Lyle, Reigner,
and Dietz. The losers' lone tally was
made in the final seconds by Chilnick
on a pass from Warfe.
The Pi Lambda Phi team, last year's
titlists, held a practice session so as
to settle the plays and positions of the
men. Wall and Breslau, both freshmen,
showed promise and gave signs that
they will have to be feared by opponents in actual games.
- Games will now continue until
Thanksgiving when the winners of
the leagues will be known. Immediately after the vacation a play off
will be held for the fraternity championship.

We have little advice to offer. We
have so little, in fact, that we nearly
waived our traditional advice-giving
privilege, hoping that their tumbles
into the great pitfalls of college life
would act as a better conditioner to

We are weak, though. We shall advise --once. And, what is worse, our
admonition is a don't. It is: "Don't
try to be a 'big man' on the campus.
Activities, most of the saner observers
of undergraduate life will aver, are
a salutary force in the life of the undengrad, but there is no more real
waste of the opportunity that college
offers than to tackle more activities
than you can handle. For all, except
potential Thomas A. Edisoru3, two activities should be a man's limit. If you
attempt more, the chance are about
five to one that you will either fail
to get the most out of your studies
or that you will bungle the activities.
You will probably do both."

leave it. Go out for one or two activou will really enjoy the expe't keep your eyes the same

a group matter; of people working together to create the play as the playwrite conceived it. His greatest joy
is when some awkward youngster succeeds in feeling the part through his
whole body, and at last really belongs
to it. And then to see the effect of that
on the whole troupe.
So they come. Every year applications of hopefuls pour in. Only a few
can be accomodated. Some come, grow
discouraged, and leave. Others find
Openings in New York, Hollywood, or
some other Little Theatre group. A
few are successful as a result. Many
fit into parts in stock companies. And
then, of course, there are those who
stick. Stick because this gives them a
manner of living, a reason for living. To work and be always working,
to find something to be done everyminute. Satisfied with the theatre
they have got, glad to produce the
great plays of masters, and equally
happy to try some one of the many
manuscripts which pour into the mail
boxes, they try plays of seasons ago,
or of seasons to come. They welcome
any audiences, by not caring for the
audiences.
This troupe will be seen here in
Baltimore at the Auditorium, for
two performances on November 18. In
the afternoon, the play will be "The
Emperor's New Clothes." In the evening, Bernard Shaw's biting satire,
"Getting Married," will be shown. This
is the opening bill of the Hopkins
Playhouse, under the direction of Dr.
N. B. Fagin.

Dr. McClure Speaks
On International Pacts
Dr. Wallace McClure, of the Departtrient of State in Washington, yesterday delivered the first of a series
of lectures on "Problems Concerning
International Agreement Under the
American Form of Government. Every
Thursday hereafter at 11.30 he will
continue his series in Gilman Hall.
During the second semester he will
devote his time to the "Intimations
Of World Government." This topic will
be a sequel to the first and clarify
lasues stirred up by it.
This series was made possible by
Theodore Marburg, a trustee of the
University and a former United States
arnba.ssador to Belgium.

Home Appearance
Gardner Mallonee's gridiron valiants stage their first home performance of the current season tonight
when they confront the Washington
College aggregation at the Homewood
Field.
The Jays will be seeking their first
victory over the Chestertown lads in
three years. Time there was when
the Washington tussle was merely
a warm-up drill for the Blue Jays
who concentrated upon other, more
potential, opponents. But tonight the
Hopkins team will be fighting madly
to humble an opponent which has
assumed a significant position on the
grid card.
Two years ago, a highly confident
Jay squad was upset by a welltrained, aggresive, and determined
Maroon eleven. To add to the humiliation of the defeat, Gibby Young,
elusive diminuitive quarterback, intercepted a pass behind Ns own goal
line, and twisting and dodging, reeled
off a 103 yard run to score a brilliant
touchdown last season.
A definitely superior Washington
squad downed a scrappy Hopkins
team by a narrow margin.
Thus the gridmen are intent upon
stemming the maroon and black tide
and enjoying a victory of vengeance.
The outcome of this evenings contest is significant in view of another
consideration. A Hopkins eleven has
failed to break into the win column
since 1934.

Still hungry for their firSt victory
of the season. the Blue Jay Booters
meet Salisbury State Teachers College tomorrow at Homewood. Smaring under last week's defeat at the
hands of Gettysburg, the team seeks
vengeance on its new opposition.
The Booters, already acknowledged
powerful defense is further strengthened by the return of Hartman after
an absence. At his old goalie post,
Hartman is playing the best soccer
of his career. From soccer-conscious
Greensboro High comes a new acquisition, Briggs, center forward, who,
together with Phillips, Hartke, and
Clisham, gives promise of building
up a Hopkins offensive to rival its

tine defense. And coupled with this
is Coach Frank Dotterweich's assurance that the Hopkins' team is now
supplied with the necessary stamina
to show the shoremen plenty of speed
on attack and defense. His conviction
is borne out by the fine exhibition of
offensive play at last Saturday's Gettysburg game, and the usual excellent defense, in spite of the fact that
the Jays went down in defeat in extra
periods.

The interfraternity touch football
league got off to its scheduled start
on Tuesday with the Sigma Phi Epsilon team registering a 24 to 6 victory over the Alpha Epsilon Pi representatives. At no time were the winners hard pressed and they contented
themselves with trying out their plays
rather than attempting to pile up a
huge score. Those scoring touchdowns
for the victors were Lyle, Reigner,
and Dietz. The losers' lone tally was
made in the final seconds by Chilnick
on a pass from Warfe.
The Pi Lambda Phi team, last year's
titlists, held a practice session so as
to settle the plays and positions of the
men. Wall and Breslau, both freshmen,
showed promise and gave signs that
they will have to be feared by opponents in actual games.
- Games will now continue until
Thanksgiving when the winners of
the leagues will be known. Immediately after the vacation a play off
will be held for the fraternity championship.
